metadata.title: Amine-functionalized MgAl LDH nanosheets as efficient solid base catalysts for Knoevenagel condensation

Table 3 Entry A B Conversion of aldehyde (%) Selectivity (%) 1 95.6 >99 2 96.6 >99 3 99.4 >99 4 98.7 >99 5 87.6 >99 6 94.3 >99 7 94.1 >99 8 97.5 >99 Reaction condition: aldehyde 1.9 mmol, malononitrile or ethyl cyanoacetate 1.9 mmol, toluene 10 mL, catalyst 0.06 g, reaction time 1 h, reaction temperature 40 °C. Amine-functionalized MgAl LDH nanosheets as efficient solid base catalysts for Knoevenagel condensation Huanhuan Jia a Yuan Zhao a Panpan Niu a Ningyue Lu a Binbin Fan a ⁎ Ruifeng Li a b ⁎ a College of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Taiyuan University of Technology, Taiyuan, 030024, PR China College of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering Taiyuan University of Technology Taiyuan 030024 PR China b Key Laboratory of Coal Science and Technology MOE, Taiyuan University of Technology, Taiyuan, 030024, PR China Key Laboratory of Coal Science and Technology MOE Taiyuan University of Technology Taiyuan 030024 PR China ⁎ Corresponding authors at: College of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Taiyuan University of Technology, Taiyuan, 030024, PR China. College of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering Taiyuan University of Technology Taiyuan 030024 PR China Graphical abstract In this work, an efficient base catalyst, amine-functionalized MgAl LDH nanosheet, was prepared by grafting aminopropyltriethoxysilane (APTS) on MgAl LDH nanosheets via the condensation between the ethyoxyl groups of APTS and the hydroxyl groups on the surface of MgAl LDH nanosheets. The physical-chemical properties of the prepared samples were characterized by XRD, FT-IR, N2 adsorption-desorption, TG, SEM, CO2 adsorption and catalytic reactions. The results showed that APTS could be successfully grafted on MgAl LDH nanosheets due to their high surface area and more available and accessible −OH groups. The prepared amine-functionalized MgAl LDH nanosheets showed excellent catalytic performance in Knoevenagel condensation due to the synergistic effects among the grafted amine groups, the LDH nanosheets and reaction substrates. Moreover, the prepared catalysts can be used to catalyze various Knoevenagel condensations, and have well reusability. This method supplies an effective way to fabricate novel base catalysts based on LDHs. Keywords LDH Nanosheets Delamination APTS Knoevenagel condensation 1 Introduction Knoevenagel condensation, one of the most important carbon–carbon bond formation methodologies in synthesis of numerous special chemicals and chemical intermediates [1], is generally catalyzed by homogeneous base catalysts [2–4]. However, the homogeneous catalysts are difficult to be separated and recovered from the reaction mixtures and cannot meet the increasingly stringent requirements for environmental benignity and sustainability. Hence, heterogeneous catalysts, including Lewis acids [5], sulfate-ion promoted zirconia [6], nitrogen doped carbon [7] and amine-functionalized polyacrylonitrile fiber [8], silicas [9,10], MOFs [11], graphene oxide [12], etc, have recently been employed to catalyze Knoevenagel condensation. Among these reported heterogeneous catalysts, various amine-functionalized catalysts have received intense interests. For Knoevenagel condensation, it can proceed on pairs of Lewis basic and acidic sites reaching different activity and selectivity [13]. Therefore, the properties of the supports have significant effects on the catalytic performance of the resultant amine-functionalized materials. The ideal supports not only can provide the anchoring sites for amine groups, but also can bring synergy to facilitate the reaction through the interaction between support and reaction substrates. Gao et al. [14] showed that amine functionalized UiO-66-NH2 metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) with Lewis acid Zr sites and base −NH2 sites are more active and selective than bare UiO-66 in Knoevenagel condensation of benzaldehyde with malononitrile. ZIF-8 with base sites (derived from 2-methylimidazolate anions) and Lewis acid sites (derived from Zn2+ cations) was also found to be beneficial for promoting Knoevenagel condensation [15]. Xia et al. [16] have shown that the incorporation of weak acid sites next to amine-sites is favorable to the overall reaction rate. However, for amine-containing MOFs or ZIF-8, their practical applicability is usually limited to some extent by their intrinsically microporous structures, while for the conventional SiO2 support, due to its very weak acid sites, normally need introducing new types of hydroxyl groups to engineer the surface silanol groups. Therefore, it is of high importance to develop or select appropriate supports that can optimize the various natures of grafted amine groups, and eventually promote their activity in Knoevenagel reaction. Layered double hydroxide (LDH), a kind of typical layered clay minerals, is composed of positively charged two-dimensional brucite-type octahedral layers and interlayer anions. LDHs have progressively received much attention as catalysts or supports due to their surface acid–base properties [17–19]. Therefore, LDHs are potential supports for preparation of amine-functionalized catalysts. However, LDHs prepared by the conventional co-precipitation was severely aggregated due to the high surface charge and the hydrophilic of LDH sheets. As a consequence, LDHs usually have low surface areas and cannot provide enough exposed surface hydroxyl groups for grafting amine groups [20]. To overcome this problem, delamination of LDHs has attracted much attention. After delamination, the obtained LDH nanosheets were highly dispersive and gave large surface areas which not only can increase the anchoring sites for amine groups, but also can facilitate the mass transport of reagents to and from the surface [21,22]. However, LDHs are difficult to be delaminated due to their high formal charge density and the strong interactions between adjacent layers [23–25]. Delamination of LDHs generally needs inserting an anion into the interlayer to increase the interlayer distance by swelling with an appropriate solvent and then delaminating the swollen LDH structure in an appropriate solvent/dispersant medium [24]. Nevertheless, this method suffers from high solvent consumption, low yields and difficult isolation of the delaminated LDH nanosheets from the solvent dispersion while avoiding aggregation. Recently, a new aqueous miscible organic solvent treatment (AMOST) method has been developed for the large-scale high yield synthesis of highly porous dispersed LDH powders containing delaminated nanosheets [26]. This method provides a new opportunity for the application of LDH nanosheets as catalyst supports. In this paper, amine-functionalized MgAl LDH nanosheets were prepared by grafting APTS onto the surface of LDH nanosheets and used as solid base catalysts for Knoevenagel condensation. The unique acid-basic properties and high surface area of MgAl LDH nanosheets showed significant support advantages as compared to other conventional supports, and the prepared amine-functionalized MgAl LDH nanosheets gave excellent catalytic performance in Knoevenagel condensation. 2 Experimental 2.1 Chemical reagents Aminopropyltriethoxysilane (APTS), malononitrile, ethyl cyanoacetate, 4-methoxy-benzaldehyde，1-naphthaldehyde, 4-methyl-benzaldehyde were purchased from Alfa Aesar. SiO2 and Al2O3 were obtained from Nankai University Catalyst Co., Ltd. Other chemical reagents were obtained from Sinopharm Chem. Reagent Co., Ltd. All the reagents were used as received without further purification. 2.2 Catalyst preparation MgAl LDH nanosheets were synthesized according to the AMOST method described in the literature [26]. 40 mL of aqueous solution of Mg(NO3)2·6H2O (30 mmol) and Al(NO3)3·9H2O (10 mmol) was dropped into 100 mL of H3BO3 solution under vigorous stirring. The pH of the mixture solution was maintained at 9 by adjusting with 1.5 M NaOH solution. The resultant gel-like slurry was stirred at room temperature for 10 min and then aged at 65 °C for 24 h. After filtration, the obtained white solid product firstly was washed with deioned decarbonated water (DD water) until neutral, and then was washed with acetone and dried at 65 °C overnight. The obtained sample was denoted as MgAl-LDH-NS. For comparison, the conventional MgAl-LDH sample was also prepared by the coprecipitation method [27], and the obtained sample was denoted as MgAl-LDH. APTS functionalized sample was prepared according to the literature with some modification [28]. Typically, 30 mL of toluene was added to 1.0 g of support (MgAl-LDH-NS, MgAl-LDH, Al2O3 or SiO2) at 110 °C in an oil bath under Ar flow. After stirring for 0.5 h, 2.168 mmol of APTS dissolved in 20 mL of toluene was added and the mixture was continuously stirred for 12 h. After that the sample was extracted by ethanol for 24 h and dried at 80 °C overnight. The obtained sample was denoted as NH2-MgAl-LDH-NS, NH2-MgAl-LDH, NH2-Al2O3 and NH2-SiO2, respectively. By adjusting the APTS amount (APTS/LDH = 0.542, 1.084 and 4.336 mmol/g) in the grafting process, a series of NH2-MgAl-LDH-NS samples with different −NH2 amounts were prepared. The obtained samples were denoted as NH2-MgAl-LDH-NS-1, NH2-MgAl-LDH-NS-2 and NH2-MgAl-LDH-NS-3, respectively. 2.3 Characterization Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) measurement was performed on a Shimadzu XRD-6000 diffractometer by using Cu Kα radiation over a 2θ range from 5 to 65 °. FT-IR spectra were recorded by a SHIMADZU FTIR-Affinity-1 spectrometer using the conventional KBr pellet method. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) image was taken on a Hitachi S-4800 instrument. N2 adsorption was performed at 77 K using a Quantachrone Nova 1200e apparatus and the surface area was calculated by the BET method. CO2 adsorption was carried out at 25 °C on a Quantachrone Nova 1000 apparatus. The sample was evacuated at 150 °C for 5 h before N2 or CO2 adsorption measurement. TG analysis was carried on a STA 449 F3 between 25 and 650 °C with a heating rate of 10 °C/min under air atmosphere. The N contents of NH2-Al2O3 and NH2-SiO2 were determined by a varioELcube elemental analyzer and N contents of NH2-MgAl-LDH and NH2-MgAl-LDH-NS were calculated from the Si contents measured by inductively coupled plasma (ICP) analysis. 2.4 Catalytic reaction Knoevenagel condensation between benzaldehyde/4-methoxy-benzaldehyde/4-methyl-benzaldehyde/1-naphthaldehyde and malononitrile (X = CN)/ethyl cyanoacetate (X = COOEt) (Scheme 1 ) was carried out in a 25 mL two-neck flask with a magnetic stirring bar and condenser. Typically, the powdered catalyst (0.06 g) was added to 10 mL of toluene containing two kinds of substrates (1.9 mmol, respectively), and then the mixture was stirred in a thermostatic water bath. After reaction, the catalyst was separated by centrifugation, and the liquid products were identified by a GCMS-QP2010 SE and analyzed using a SHIMADZU GC-2014 equipped with a FID detector and a RTX-1 capillary column. The separated products from the reaction with ethyl cyanoacetate as the substrate were analyzed by 1H NMR. 1H NMR spectra were recorded on Bruker Avance III (400 MHz) instrument with CDCl3 as the solvent. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization 3.1.1 XRD The XRD patterns of the prepared different samples are shown in Fig. 1 . As shown in Fig. 1, MgAl-LDH prepared by the conventional co-precipitation method showed the typical LDH diffraction peaks. No characteristic Bragg reflections of LDHs was observed in the XRD pattern of MgAl-LDH-NS obtained by AMOST method, whereas a series of LDH characteristic diffraction peaks appeared upon treating MgAl-LDH-NS with Na2CO3 aqueous solution, even if these diffraction peaks significantly widen. These results indicated that MgAl-LDH-NS was completely delaminated into single sheets [26], and the delaminated LDH nanosheets could restacked into their layered structure in Na2CO3 aqueous solution. Upon grafting APTS, the obtained NH2-MgAl-LDH and NH2-MgAl-LDH-NS displayed almost the same reflections as their precursors. However, different from MgAl-LDH-NS, only very weak LDH characteristic reflections were observed upon treating NH2-MgAl-LDH in Na2CO3 aqueous solutions, indicating that APTS grafted on MgAl-LDH-NS seriously influenced the restack of LDH nanosheets and decreased the order degree of the restacked sample. This perhaps resulted from the higher hydrophobicity of NH2-MgAl-LDH-NS, which weakened the interlayer interaction [21]. The inhibition of the grafted APTS on the restack of MgAl-LDH-NS has positive role on keeping the high surface area of the catalyst and accessibility of the grafted amine groups. 3.1.2 FT-IR The FT-IR spectra of MgAl-LDH-NS and NH2-MgAl-LDH-NS are shown in Fig. 2 . MgAl-LDH-NS and NH2-MgAl-LDH-NS showed nearly the same bands, in which the band at about 1385 cm−1 for the two samples was ascribed to the ν3 stretching vibration of nitrate anions [29]. Upon grafting ATPS, the bands at 2923 and 2856 cm−1 assigned to the asymmetric and symmetric CH stretching modes of CH2 groups in APTS [30,31] and the band at 1572 cm−1 attributed to the symmetric bending vibration of −NH2 [32] could be clearly observed in the spectrum of NH2-MgAl-LDH-NS. These results confirmed that APTS was successfully grafted on the surface of MgAl-LDH-NS. The successfully grafting APTS on MgAl-LDH-NS can be further confirmed by CO2 adsorption and TG analysis. 3.1.3 CO2 adsorption The CO2 adsorption isotherms of the different samples are displayed in Fig. 3 . From Fig. 3, it can be seen that all the samples exhibited distinctive adsorption trend under the low relative pressure. Compared with MgAl-LDH-NS, a series of NH2-MgAl-LDH-NS samples displayed higher adsorption amount, and the adsorption amount increased with the APTS loadings due to the affinity adsorption of CO2 to the grafted amine groups. These results further provide strong evidences for successfully grafting APTS on MgAl-LDH-NS from another point of view. 3.1.4 TG analysis Fig. 4 shows the TG curves of MgAl-LDH-NS and NH2-MgAl-LDH-NS. Both two samples shows three mass loss steps, namely, (i) desorption of physically adsorbed acetone (between room temperature and 120 °C), (ii) dehydroxylation of the brucite-like sheets (120–280 °C) and (iii) the decomposition of the interlayer anions or the grafted organic silane (280–550 °C). However, two samples gave different mass loss in (ii) and (iii) steps. The 7.6% mass loss recorded in (ii) step for NH2-MgAl-LDH-NS is lower than the 9.4% for MgAl-LDH-NS. This is mainly due to the consumption of some −OH groups on the surface of MgAl-LDH-NS in the grafting process. In (iii) step, the mass loss for NH2-MgAl-LDH-NS was 19.4%, larger than 13.0% for MgAl-LDH-NS. The extra mass loss for NH2-MgAl-LDH-NS mainly came from the decomposition of the grafted APTS. This result further confirmed that APTS was successfully grafted on MgAl-LDH-NS. 3.1.5 SEM Fig. 5 displays the SEM images of MgAl-LDH-NS and NH2-MgAl-LDH-NS. MgAl-LDH-NS was rose-petal like aggregates of planar sheet morphology, while NH2-MgAl-LDH-NS were the curved single layers and the adjacent layer was linked with each other. Compared to MgAl-LDH-NS, NH2-MgAl-LDH-NS was more dispersive and fluffy. 3.1.6 N2 adsorption-desorption The N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms were employed to evaluate the textural properties of the different samples, and the surface area and pore volume of the different samples are listed in Table 1 . From Table 1, it can be seen that the surface area of MgAl-LDH-NS was much larger than MgAl-LDH, further indicating that the prepared sample was successfully delaminated. Upon functionalization of MgAl-LDH-NS with APTS, the surface areas and pore volumes of a series of NH2-MgAl-LDH-NS samples were further enhanced, and increased with the grafted APTS amount until APTS loading reached 0.694 mmol/g. This maybe is due to the following two reasons: (i) the grafted the APTS can increased the hydrophobicity of the MgAl-LDH-NS via consumption part of the −OH groups, thus decreasing the aggregating degree among LDH nanosheets; (ii) the grafted APTS can condense with the neighboring LDH particles to form the linked oligomers, which can generate extra mesopores and contribute to the dramatic increase of total pore volumes [30,33]. As the grafted APTS amount continued increase, the textural parameters almost kept unchanged which was probably ascribed to the self-aggregation of the excess grafted silane during the grafting process [34,35]. 3.2 Catalytic performance 3.2.1 Catalytic performance of different samples Benzaldehyde and malononitrile were chosen as the reaction substrates to investigate the catalytic performance of a series of NH2-MgAl-LDH-NS samples for Knoevenagel condensation, and the results are shown in Table 2 . The conversion of benzaldehyde was only 1.5% in the absence of any catalyst (Entry 1). And little improvement in the conversion of benzaldehyde was obtained by using MgAl-LDH-NS as the catalyst (Entry 2), indicating that alone MgAl-LDH-NS only showed very low activity (10.5%) under the employed reaction conditions. In contrast, very high benzaldehyde conversion (95.6%) over NH2-MgAl-LDH-NS was observed (Entry 6). These results demonstrated that the −NH2 groups grafted on MgAl-LDH-NS were the main active sites in the reaction. Moreover, from Table 2, it can be seen that the catalytic activities significantly increased with increasing grafted −NH2 amounts until the APTS loading reached 0.694 mmol/g (Entry 4–6). This result further indicated that −NH2 groups grafted on MgAl-LDH-NS were the main active sites, and for NH2-MgAl-LDH-NS samples, their catalytic activities greatly depended on the available −NH2 numbers on the surface of the catalysts. A further increase APTS loading (Entry 7) had no a significant effect. This is due to the nearly complete conversion of benzaldehyde. The reaction product obtained over different samples was benzylidene malononitrile and no other by-products were detected. Besides, the catalytic performance over APTS and the mixture of APTS and MgAl-LDH-NS were also investigated, and the conversions obtained over the two catalysts were only 14.8% and 22.0% (Entry 3 and 8), respectively, which were quite lower than that obtained over the prepared heterogeneous catalyst. From this result, it can be inferred that there is a synergistic effect between the active -NH2 groups and support, and the synergistic effect is closely related to the intimacy of the grafted −NH2 groups and the MgAl-LDH-NS. For comparison, a series of amine-functionalized catalysts were prepared by the same method using MgAl-LDH, the conventional Al2O3 and SiO2 as the supports, and their catalytic performance in the Knoevenagel condensation were compared. As shown in Table 2, the −NH2 amount grafted on MgAl-LDH was far below those on other three supports, even if all the catalysts were prepared under the identical conditions. This is mainly due to that MgAl-LDH is heavily aggregated and has a low surface area, which resulted in that the −OH amount exposed on the surface for grafting APTS is very low and APTS is difficult to be grafted on MgAl-LDH. Accordingly, NH2-MgAl-LDH had low −NH2 amount and gave low catalytic activity (Entry 9) in Knoevenagel condensation. NH2-SiO2 and NH2-Al2O3 have a little more −NH2 amounts than NH2-MgAl-LDH-NS, but they gave lower catalytic activities. In order to further reveal the support effects of MgAl LDH nanosheets, the TOF values of the different amine-functionalized catalyst were calculated at low conversions and the related results were also listed in Table 2. It is clear that -NH2 groups grafted on MgAl-LDH-NS gave much higher TOF than those on SiO2 and Al2O3, and MgAl-LDH-NS displayed excellent support effects. Moreover, the NH2-MgAl-LDH-NS samples with the different grafted -NH2 amounts gave the similar TOF values (Entry14-17), indicating that the grafted -NH2 group will act as a single active site for this reaction [36]. For amine functionalized catalysts, their catalytic role in Knoevenagel reaction generally can be explained via two mechanisms. One involves imine intermediate pathway [37,38], while the other involves generating carboanions, forming oxyanion and eliminating water [39]. No matter whatever mechanism the reaction may be, NH2-MgAl-LDH-NS with acid-base dual sites have a great promotion on the reaction. The grafted −NH2 groups, as strong base sites, contribute to trap of protons from the active methylene group of malononitrile so as to accelerate the formation of aminocation and carboanion or undergo nucleophilic attack on the carbonyl carbon to form the imine intermediate, while the positive metal cations on MgAl-LDH-NS can act as Lewis acid sites and interact with the oxygen of a carbonyl group in benzaldehyde, through which the CO bond is further polarized with the increase in the positive charge on the carbon of the carbonyl group. Consequently, for NH2-MgAl-LDH-NS, its high activity in Knoevenagel condensation can be mainly ascribed to the following two aspects: i) the MgAl-LDH-NS with high surface area, provide more available and accessible −OH groups for grafting APTS; ii) the synergistic effects among MgAl LDHs, the grafted −NH2 groups and reaction substrates contribute to the increased catalytic activities. 3.2.2 Effects of reaction conditions on the catalytic performance As shown in Fig. 6 , a significant increase in benzaldehyde conversion was observed as the catalyst amount increased from 0 to 0.06 g, and the conversion could reach 96% after reacting 1 h at 0.06 g catalyst. A further increase in catalyst amount no long brought significant enhancement in benzaldehyde conversion. Fig. 7 shows the effect of reaction time and temperature on the catalytic performance over NH2-MgAl-LDH-NS. It could be obviously seen that the benzaldehyde conversion increased gradually as the reaction progressed. At the same time, with the increase of the reaction temperature, the substrate conversion also displayed an increasing trend. 3.2.3 Knoevenagel condensation with different substrates The catalytic results of NH2-MgAl-LDH-NS in the Knoevenagel condensations with different reaction substrates are summarized in Table 3 . In the all cases, the selectivities were above 99%. 1H NMR data of the products in Entry (5–8) (See Supporting information) were in accordance with the data of the E configuration substances reported in the literatures [40,41]. Clearly, NH2-MgAl-LDH-NS exhibited high catalytic activities in the reactions with the different reaction substrates, and can be used in various Knoevenagel condensations. 3.2.4 Catalytic stability of NH2-MgAl-LDH-NS in knoevenagel condensation Fig. 8 is the catalytic results for NH2-MgAl-LDH-NS in Knoevenagel condensation of benzaldehyde and malononitrile with six repeated recycles. The fresh NH2-MgAl-LDH-NS showed a benzaldehyde conversion of 95.6%. If the spent catalyst was just regenerated by filtration before the next reaction run, its catalytic activity sharply decreased, as evidenced by the result that the benzaldehyde conversion decreased to 36.0% after six recycles (Fig. 8a). If the spent catalyst recovered from toluene after six recycles was washed with methanol and reused again, its activity increased to 85.1% from 36.0%. Moreover, when the reaction was performed for 10 min, the catalyst was separated from the reaction mixture, and left the reaction for another 50 min. It was found that the benzaldehyde conversion still remained at 62.5% without a further increase. Therefore, the decreasing activity for the spent NH2-MgAl-LDH-NS in toluene maybe is due to adsorbing strong-polar substance instead of APTS leaching. When the reaction was carried out in methanol (Fig. 8b), the benzaldehyde conversion still reached 84.9% after such six repeated recycles. The results verified that the prepared NH2-MgAl-LDH-NS could be reused in appropriate reaction conditions. In addition, in order to avoid the occurrence of transesterification when ethyl cyanoacetate was used as substrate, the reusability of NH2-MgAl-LDH-NS in ethanol with ethyl cyanoacetate as substrate was also investigated. As shown in Fig. 8c, no obvious loss of activity was observed after six recycles. 4 Conclusions Amine-functionalized MgAl LDH nanosheets were successfully prepared by grafting APTS onto the surface of the MgAl LDH nanosheets via condensation reaction between the −OH groups on the LDH layers and the ethyoxyl groups of APTS. The prepared NH2-MgAl-LDH-NS catalysts exhibited excellent performance in the Knoevenagel condensation compared to the homogeneous catalyst APTS and the heterogeneous catalysts with Al2O3 and SiO2 as the other supports. The excellent catalytic behavior for the prepared NH2-MgAl-LDH-NS can be mainly ascribed to the high surface area of MgAl LDH nanosheets and synergistic effects among MgAl LDHs, the grafted −NH2 groups and reaction substrates. This work provides an effective way to fabricate novel base catalysts based on LDHs. Acknowledgment This work is supported by the National Science Foundation of China (No. 21576177 and 20971095). Appendix A Supplementary data Supplementary data associated with this article can be found, in the online version, at http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.mcat.2018.02.004. coredata.dc:description: In this work, an efficient base catalyst, amine-functionalized MgAl LDH nanosheet, was prepared by grafting aminopropyltriethoxysilane (APTS) on MgAl LDH nanosheets via the condensation between the ethyoxyl groups of APTS and the hydroxyl groups on the surface of MgAl LDH nanosheets. The physical-chemical properties of the prepared samples were characterized by XRD, FT-IR, N2 adsorption-desorption, TG, SEM, CO2 adsorption and catalytic reactions. The results showed that APTS could be successfully grafted on MgAl LDH nanosheets due to their high surface area and more available and accessible −OH groups. The prepared amine-functionalized MgAl LDH nanosheets showed excellent catalytic performance in Knoevenagel condensation due to the synergistic effects among the grafted amine groups, the LDH nanosheets and reaction substrates. Moreover, the prepared catalysts can be used to catalyze various Knoevenagel condensations, and have well reusability. This method supplies an effective way to fabricate novel base catalysts based on LDHs.
coredata.dc:title: Amine-functionalized MgAl LDH nanosheets as efficient solid base catalysts for Knoevenagel condensation
